news_header: Lloyds triples car finance scandal provisions to £1.2bn, impacting profits amid compensation concerns.
news_original_title: Lloyds sets aside £1.2bn for car loan mis-selling payouts
news_text: Lloyds Banking Group has increased its provisions for the car finance mis-selling scandal to £1.2bn, affecting its profits. The bank set aside an additional £700m for potential compensation, on top of £450m previously allocated. Lloyds is facing scrutiny over unclear commission payments to car dealers, with millions of motorists potentially eligible for compensation. Despite this, CEO Charlie Nunn stated that the bank's overall performance remains strong, reporting a pre-tax profit of £5.97bn, down from £7.5bn the previous year. The Supreme Court is set to rule on the adequacy of information provided to car loan customers regarding commission payments. Other banks have also made provisions for compensation related to motor finance.
